comments.commentBody: Of course Fox will not suspend oh Riley. He brings into much advertising revenue to do that. That's all Fox cares about.
Not exactly. O'Reilly was a real life working journalist when he "reported" on the events in question. If he exaggerated or flatly lied, he deserves the same treatment Williams is getting.
True, he is by no means a journalist now, but, the allegations now discussed involve when he was a journalist for CBS news.

No one should get all hot and bothered about Billo's upset.  After all, he's not a journalist, but rather an opinion writer.  He's entitled to his views.  And he's also an entertainer when it comes to his live-action curriculum vitae.  No need to worry about whether he'd fabricate a news story, as he does not do news stories.

I think the hope is that more people become more acutely aware that the "bullying charlatan" works for a faux "news" outfit that will, in fact, let O'Reilly slide for something that got a real reporter fired.
Fox News is Bill O'Reilly without whom the phoney News Show would not be . So how could they get rid of their main event. People are free to beleive what they want even fake reporting.
Well that doesn't make it right.......and another reason to despise FAUX network and news.

Williams was paid to be a handsome actor/teleprompter reader/news reporter and managed to cultivate a reputation of honesty and trustworthiness. Those who think all network news is infotainment knew better, but the illusion was semi-credibly maintained.

O'Reilly, on the other hand, is paid to be a propagandist, not a reporter, and is widely understood to be a bullying charlatan. He lied about the Falklands War? So what: it's consistent with the rest of his oeuvre. You think FOX will fire him for this? I don't think so: they are probably laughing in their executive suites that the public would make a stink over this.

....Look what you've done!! I'm melting, melting. Ohhhhh, what a world, what a world. Who would have thought that some little reporter and magazine like you could destroy my beautiful bloviations.

The truth be the water in this case. How hard the self-righteous do fall!
Finally a note of hope.

Maybe Mr. O'Reilly's next tome in his "Killing" series will be: Killing the Truth.
Roger Ailes is probably having a coronary over his cash cow.

One might suggest he simply call his show "entertainment" as the WWF did when it was shown that all of the so called "bouts" or fights and challenges in it's shows were rigged and fake.
But few lovers of TV wrestling shows cared, and keep threatening and challenging nay sayers and causing real damage when they drunklenly throw punches or badly understood but dangerous wrestling holds on innocent people, in order to show "how real WWF is!". The new Wrestling "entertainment shows" are even more popular, and their fans don't seem to understand,(or care), that there is any difference between entertainment wrestling by professional fall takers and real wrestling as in Japanese and classic Greco-Roman.
The worst of WWF was that children trying out throws seen on TV often ended scarred and crippled for life. This is also true for Oreilly's fans who, believing him to be a real newsperson, end up intellectually scarred and crippled for life-totally unable and unwilling to carry on the necessary verbal dialog is needed by all democracies, without threatening and insulting others.

Poor Bill. At least seven of his former colleagues who were in Argentina with him have stated his assertions are less than truthful.  His response is to scream, yell, deny, and accuse. Mr. O'Reilly needs to find a few correspondents to corroborate his story -- until he does so his cries of a "political hit job" (whatever that means) are silly and his claims of bravery in midst of war are simply not believable.

This article is so mild and vague regarding the charges against Bill O'Reilly that a reader would have no idea of what the issue is, if it were not for the comments.  O'Reilly obviously intimidated Howard Kurtz when Kurtz interviewed him---is he even going to intimidate the NYTimes?
He wrote and said that he was in the Falklands. Those were lies.
He answered the charges quite admirably and with documentation. He called Mr Corn no names ecept to point out this was a partisan attack.  Get your facts straight.

Mr O'Reilly has very little credibility.....This is the same man who had to settle a sexual harassment lawsuit in 2004 to Andrea Mackris, after originally denying the charges...She had his remarks on tape..

When you watch O'Reilly in the charges of embellishing the Falklands conflict, he's not answering the charges at all, he's merely engaging in an ad-hominem attack calling David Corn every name in the book....Usually when one resorts to the ad-hominem attack, your on the losing side of the argument...
And the moon is made of green cheese

He is a brutal and increasingly sicker man whose blood pressure is no longer under control and whose "executive functions: are losing out to the ancient hind brain. He recently almost attacked his own "liberal lap dog" commentator , accusing him of being a Liar for having his own opinion and, when he was unable to satisfy Oreilly's idea of what constituted proof or evdence, Oreilly threatened him. There is no such thing as reasoned debate or discussion of his shows and the FCC ought to take note. That ignorant Americans, whose knowledge of what constitutes reporting as a public service, as FCC license holders are required to supply, is often nonexistent, ( something which all US TV stations are expected to participate to keep their licenses, which are the people's property), and they may enjoy his red faced , barroom challenges. This is hardly news, itself. They also like Wrestling shows and so called Reality TV which are all made up of cheap,  and easy to construct , film and edit "game-like" ideas out of failed summer camp color wars or stolen off Korean TV.
And how do you arrive at that opinion? Pls explain
I support Mr. O´Reilly. I think he´s a decent and honest man.

I think the story of the CBS newsmen is:
he said, he said, he said, he said, he said, he said, he said Vs. Bill said.

Yet another example of "he said, she said" journalism, which one hopes would never appear in the New York Times. Fox News is nothing but a propaganda channel and always has been. Bill O'Reilly is a chief Fox propagandist. To pretend otherwise is to ignore the facts.
Jon Stewart is the only man in America who could actually get O'Reilly off the hook, if he wanted to. Let's see what happens.
Jon Stewart and O'Reilly get along just fine.  They often appear together.  It seems you're unaware of that.  Try watching Fox once in a while.  It might enlighten you.
Stewart kid gloves O'Reilly. Colbert, where are you? John Oliver?
Send Jon Stewart to O'Reilly's show.  He'd get O'Reilly set straight in a heartbeat.
Abbots refers to all of us who watch the abbey - Downton Abbey that is.  Hello fellow Abbots!

@Marjie Callaway VA

Bravo! -- Great tip.
Yes, it was rather anachronistic as was Lord Grantham's use of the term "parallel universe" earlier in the episode whilst discussing the tombstones.
I don't think Shakespeare is "stuffy" and he most certainly is "restricted to certain phrases."

Re: Edith's comment to her father, to "give it up", re: his hope that Lady Mary & Lord Gillingham would resume their romance,  sounded inauthentic. I think this is a  modern expression, not one used in the circa 1939 period that the Downton show is at at this point.
I believe you meant "Anna," not "Mary."
And unbearably and annoyingly PC for the early 20s!
i would bet pbs has no creative input on DA whatsoever
You made that point last week.  No need to repeat yourself.

For all its shortcomings, and I agree, the Mr. Green plot is awful, I've found this season to be perhaps the show's best. It's said that no program, comedy or drama, can succeed unless the audience is made to care about the characters and I think this is DA's greatest strength. Whether it's a scene with Violet and Isobel or Mary and Mr. Carson, I find myself carrying deeply about these characters that I won't forget, even after the series is over. Looking forward to next week!

comments.userLocation: Lost in the wilds of Maryland
comments.commentBody:
Russia is significantly worse on transport deaths than the U.S., but I would have expected Russia to be two times worse. Is it possible that some of the data is misreported? Under reported?

Judging from the crashes shown on youtube, something is really wrong in Russia. It is not just that they have lots of crashes, it is the really dumb, stupid crashes that are shown happening again and again, as if the entire driving population has a death wish. Cars will suddenly make a left turn from the curb or a far right position. People are shown driving way too fast and then slamming into a row of stopped cars. It is utter mayhem.

We could do far better in the U.S. As cars have gotten safer in crashes, people are driving faster with less concern for others. The consensus speed in the Interstates in most areas is now above 80 mph and enforcement has gone way down. There are just too many cars speeding for police to have much impact stopping one out of 5,000 cars. Speed, however, is not the main problem.

I see texting and driving all the time and I know we are all in danger from it. I don't understand why people think they can drive and do it, but they do.

It is also clear that some states skew out national stats because they have higher death rates. Which ones?

With small dash cams and internal computers keeping track of driving, we are about to enter a golden age of reduction in highway deaths, if we study the information and apply the lessons.

http://terryreport.com
Wow! A"transformational figure?" The guy's a talented basketball 'player.' You better switch to decaf.

I hope that James' best years will come AFTER he retires from the basketball court.  Lebron is that rare, transformational, figure, that comes along once in a lifetime.  He seems to be a combination of Muhammad Ali and Dr. Martin Luther King.  He is powerful enough and popular enough to become a champion of the weak in this country, should he choose that path.  He may leave a legacy that makes basketball championships a mere footnote.
Do kids who live in the country and play in the dirt have fewer allergies than those who live in the city and spend their time indoors?

My mom gave her cats to her sister when I came along and was allergic. Much to the horror of most people today and at the time, she couldn't live without them and I ended up cohabiting happily but sneezily with them and many other animals until I left home. I grew out of the allergies and now I also have cats and dogs. I always wondered if I wouldn't have outgrown the allergies if she never brought the cats back.
Research suggests that they do.

Some older studies have suggested that infants who have two or more pets living in the home have fewer allergies as well.  Don't know whether it's the early exposure to the animal dander or the bacteria a baby might pick up from the animal or its hair.  Maybe both.  The good news is that neither of my children seems to have inherited the family hay fever and asthma, perhaps due to Fido and Kitty.
How do you know he lied? You are taking Mother Jone's word against his. Whether you like O'Reilly or not, you need to wait and see what CBS has to say.

The problem for Bill O'Reilly is his overstatements and tall tales--lies--are documented.

So all the spin in the world isn't going to change the fact that he repeatedly told one story, which was set down in print and on tape, and he is now claiming he didn't.

The truth isn't right, or left, or anything but him having hoisted himself by his own, dissembling petard.

comments.userLocation: Lost in the wilds of Maryland
comments.commentBody:
I am commenting again mainly to raise some questions.

1. The death rate in France from falling is astounding, almost as many as we have dying from transport. Something is wrong. Old houses with poor stairs? Failure to clear ice and snow? Cobblestone sidewalks?

2. Russia needs smoke detectors.

3. Could the higher death rate in India be one result of the habit of ritual washing in the holy Ganges river? Traveling about in small boats?

4. Do the statistics on poisoning include alcohol poisoning? I have been told by immigrants to the U.S. that other nations do a far better job of educating and warning young people about the dangers of alcohol. Also, perhaps the habit of giving children small sips of wine growing up in other countries helps them to develop resistance. Many people die here on their first exposure to alcohol and "doing shots", drinking whiskey straight down is celebrated in American movies featuring young people out "having a good time".

5. Any stats on accidental deaths should include medical errors, even though they are difficult to track. I have read that several hundred thousand people die every year in the U.S. from mistakes and hospital centric diseases.

http://terryreport.com

It really is bizarre and puzzling, in light of the New York Times's journalistic standards, that its presentation of the O'Reilly situation is so hazy and unclear. Why? What is wrong with stating the facts, as Corn and Schulman, supported by numerous journalists who were in Argentina with O'Reilly, have unimpeachably laid out?
She hadn't eaten breakfast.

Three hours after a supposed breakfast is not too long to go without food. How was he to know she was too nervous (whatever) to eat?

Next time the daughter will be sure to cadge some snacks out of Chris so he won't get in trouble!

No, it is not because they want to sound serious.

Half of them are bought by the private university lobby, who want to have as many useless degrees as possible, as long as they get paid (with taxpayer money). The other half know full well that large labor pools result in low labor costs for the aristocracy that they work for.

Time to stop pretending that people in congress/Washington are ignorant, including willfulness. They know exactly what they are doing - the bidding of their masters who bought their election for them.
Our all-time favorite was Summer of the Monkeys, by Wilson Rawls.  It was a bit beyond my 3-year-old but her 6-year-old brother was in stitches along with his dad and me.

Generally, if you Google or research symptoms for any drug or for withdrawal from a drug, you will probably find 50+ possible symptoms. Just look at the disclosures that come with any medication. But the percentage of people who get any one symptom is usually quite low. I think the author finally figured it out that her anxiety about withdrawal was causing the symptoms. I would suggest cognitive behavior therapy to anyone who suffers from anxiety instead of medications. If you must take medications, the SSRIs are preferable over the benzos. The benzos are very physically addictive but, worse, they mask the anxiety symptoms and cause psychological dependence.
